reviews.text:
Stunning architecture, thousands of years of history, and various places to explore. 

The Temple of Hephaestus offers guests a remarkable experience, and something everyone needs to visit. 

The overall condition of the Temple of Hephaestus is excellent, especially being thousands of years old. 

Besides the temple, there’s various pathways with monuments, statues, and sculptures. 

Spend a couple hours exploring, take lots of pictures, and enjoy thousands of years of history. 

Once your done exploring the Temple of Hephaestus, there’s tons of restaurants, cafes, and attractions within walking distance. 

I highly recommend this ancient marvel!
Absolutely stunning, best preserved temple in Athens. Plus saw wild tortoises mating which was an unexpected extra. Can guarantee the temple is amazing, can't guarantee you'll see tortoise sex.

One of the best preserved Temples in Greece, located in the Ancient Agora, you will have amazing photo opportunities with a panoramic view of Ancient Athens proper. There are some barriers for preservation purposes, it's definitely worth checking out. Added pluses are the colorful parents that best in the rafters! No tour guide necessary as all information is listed in several languages
Sits in the Acropolis among other huge temples. Definitely a must see. Be sure to wear good walking shoes. And take water, there is hose attachment to get water but it comes out hot in the summer.

Well preserved temple with less crowds than the Parthenon. Smaller, but equally impressive to look up close at the ancient structure. Get there early, before the crowds and you might be able to roam around alone, with no people getting in your way. Isn't perfect Instagram photos your goal anyways?

Site housing the remains of the Roman Forum, as well as the intact Tower of the Winds. As with the nearby Hadrian's library a full visit won't take more than an hour or so, and also it is similarly close to the main tourist areas, which you may find either convenient or less pleasant. Note that the Tower of the Winds is first closed before  visiting hours end, so if this is your last visit of the day, you may want to cross the area to go there first.

The size of the ruins is impressive. But, as many reviewers have pointed out one can appreciate it from a quick walk by. Athens is filled with ruins much more impressive. So if short on time, this is not a bucket list item.
You must visit Roman forum to feel the history. Maybe it is best in organized groups with the tour guide as Greek alphabet isn't understandable to foreign tourists. Nice location with great view.

Not much to look at. You don't have to go inside as you can watch pretty much the whole thing from the outside. The remaining structure and rubble are nice, but better ruins are preserved elsewhere in Greece, Europe and the Levant. I suspect the forum is popular mainly due to PR.
Nice to visit. Got the full pass. I recommend if you are going to Athens.

This site is beautiful and views better than a camera can capture. One of the first stops in Acropolis and really gets your mind straight on where you actually are. To imagine the type of things that were discussed and planned in this place makes it all the more special.

There is not much left unfortunately and compared to the other theatre it's not that impressive but one can imagine what it must have looked like 2000 years ago in its full glory.
This is part of the acropolis trail so you will come across it.
Fantastic piece of Greek history.  Good place to visit, with plenty of photo opportunities.
One of the first theaters in the world. It’s amazing how it could be standing almost unaltered after all these centuries.

Certainly worth visiting since it is already included in the Acropolis ticket.  If you enter from the East side, you will pass it as you climb.   Well marked history tells of it's construction and use.

It took 3 different attempt and a few Roman emperors to get this temple complete. There is not much else left but still 6 pillars.
It's part of the combined €30 acropolis ticket and offers a good backdrop to that hill.

An incredible experience! Used the complete turbopass to get here but they have great deals to see lots of attractions on the site itself too! All the locals were incredibly friendly and asking if we wanted photos taken and any help. I felt very welcome here and there was plenty of information in Greek and English to inform. I also recommend a hop on hop off sightseeing bus which is what I did and will give you more information on the audio about the Olympian and the temple of Zeus.
When I got there, there was also archaeological excavations going on which was incredible to watch especially as that's what originally got me interested at the age of 2. Even if you aren't interested in the history behind it, it's still a great site to see with family, friends or even on your own. There was lots of other ruins around too,to see and plenty of space to walk round! There is also a small shop to see. The workers are really friendly and willing to help out and have a chat!

Lucky to see this on one of the free days. Mostly in ruin the sheer size of what the columns that are left give you an idea of how impressive it would have been in its hay down. Lots to read and nice walk and right next to the arch as well
Beautiful, but not really a must see. If you have extra time on your hands go see it. You don't need more than 30-45 to walk through the small but impressive ruins.

Even though very little is left of the original temple, the size of these remains is quite impressive. One of the remaining columns collapsed during a storm in the 19th century, showing its segmented construction. The northern edge of the terrain features the foundations of various support buildings, the southern edge provides a view of the lower lying temple of Saturn and Rhea.

The view is amazing from Mount Lycabettus! You can watch Athens in every direction. It's a silent and peaceful park in the center of the city. Definitely one of the best spots in the city for some photography. Here are some shots I took on my way to the summit.

A Stunning landmark in Athens, the church was beautiful and the view from up there was breathtaking. I was lucky enough to go around sunset, which only enhanced my experience. It's a bit of a hike to get up but absolutely worth the trip. Unfortunately it's bound to be rather overcrowded on most days because of how attractive the spot is for tourists.

We went here as we had nothing else to do and it was a very good choice. A nice view over the city is offered and it is very easily reachable from the city center. You can reach the top by foot or with a cableway (7,50€ round trip).
Good hike. Nice views of Athens. Hard to find the cable ride up the hill so we ended up hiking.

It took about 30 minutes walk from Metro to top of mountain. The hike up is not difficult. The view along the way up is awesome. If you don't mind the hike, it's better than the cable car. Cable car cost €7 round trip.
It's quite windy at the top where the church is located. Many people at the top.
Amazing sunset views along the way up as well.
Recommended

Well restored national theater of Athens. Two venues inside the same building, the old historic one, beautifully kept, and a smaller space for more experimental theater. Always top level theater performances of the National Theater. You just can't go wrong by attending a theater performances there. Always too quality level word, and totally not staid!!!

My favorite theater in Athens. The building is amazing and the time you spend there always with hight quality. The area is not that safe but it worth it. Take the metro and choose omonia metro station. It is like 2’ walking from there. Do not hesitate to take an outside photo and of course to enjoy any event, just to realize the unique feeling. Sometimes there are offers on the tickets.
Such a superb place to be. Great theatrical plays on the stage, historical building with modern commodities - stage, lights, new wing!
A great theater for great plays, always enjoyed when I visit
Theater always decent but sometimes excellent

One of the best hotels I've stayed in. Perfectly situated right in the centre, with stunning views of the Acropolis if you pay a bit extra. I loved the roof-top bar and restaurant, where I had some of the best cocktails I've ever tried (but the price did reflect that) and a superb dinner. The service was impeccable and the staff friendly and informative. I would definitely stay there again.

Exceptional Hotel, great location in the middle of Athens opposite Parliament with quick access to restaurants and clothing stores. Suite was well equipped. Welcome snacks and drinks upon arrival was superb. Breakfast restaurant on the rooftop had every food you could imagine, all fresh and delicious with an amazing view of the Acropolis. Service and staff was average. But all in all a great stay!

So lovely! We had a great view of Parliament and the square. We enjoyed watching the guard. Breakfast buffet and rooftop restaurant were amazing!! The view of the Acropolis from the roof was spectacular.  The central location was handy.

If Old World luxury is your thing, this is the place. Historical 5 stars hotel in the very center of Athens, opposite parliament and home to big political gatherings and demonstrations.
Very well connected, with the metro station just outside the hotel's door, it is the best starting point to explore the near posh and less posh shopping areas.
The hotel is elegant in a discrete way, difficult to find these days. You can use the pools or enjoy the best view in Athens (the Akropolis), especially in the night, in the roof garden bar.
Only complain: no pets allowed...
Love this place. My favourite dining restaurant on the 8th. Staff so kind! Just the door man at the hotel entrance is always grumpy. Never smiles and obviously hates his job. Poor man.
Very nice view from the hill! Super nice nature around.
Interesting place. I would prefer more information about history on the spot. Entrance costs 1 €
This will preserved monastery is well worth the half day trip trip from Athens for any fans of medieval Greek architecture.

Great place to walk and get away from the stress of the city. Very quiet and peaceful.
Fresh air.
Excellent idea for a daily excursion near Athens

We went on a Thursday, which turned out to have free entry (!), and the museum is open until midnight, so we definitely felt this was very worth going. The museum itself is very cool, although a bit odd - most of the ground floor is all ancient Greek stuff (which was all great stuff, although probably more impressive if you haven't just come from the national Archaeological Museum!), but it then very rapidly transitions into Christian artwork, and then onto much more recent Greek history, including the war for independence on the top floor. We went in not knowing about any of the more recent history, so I don't think we got as much out of the more recent exhibits as we should have done.

Well laid out, authoritative, professional in every way. My focus was Byzantium, but the earlier antiquities are actually the museum's principal strength. Definitely worth visiting. Lovely gift shop and cafe as well.

We had a great experience there. The exhibition is huge and has a lot of interesting objects of art and history.

Probably the first museum where prehistoric artifacts took my breath away. The artwork is truly amazing.

Also there's a cozy canteen with nice service and a good view

One of the best museum i have been visited in Athens. Benaki museum is owned by private organization that it might be a bit more expensive, but it is totally worth the price. It has many collections of cultural artifacts in Greece from Classical to Ottoman, costumes from different regions in Greece islands.
Great museum, with a broad collection of items throughout the history of Greece! Very nice to visit for free on a Thursday evening. Good restaurant as well

The opening hours on Google are incorrect. The museum is closed on Tuesdays. It's open Monday, Wednesday to Sunday from 8:30-15:30. I wasn't able to visit the museum but wanted to let others know the correct opening hours.

Free, concise, and well laid out. The museum isn't very large, but they do a good job of presenting a lot of historical instrument usage. More instruments than description (but everything is labeled). Also a nice bathroom.
Wonderful place to see. Very old musical instruments.

Very interesting collection of Greek musical instruments. I appreciate that headphones are there for people who want to listen to the sounds of the instruments. Some headphones were not working. But can’t complain because it’s a free exhibit. All in all a must-go for music buffs.
Nice collection of instruments and audio and video samples.  Free entrance.  Not crowded.  In the center of Athens.

This museum was great. I was here for a summer program and stopped by. It was great. Very informative, interesting exhibits about Greece and stuff. Interesting to see the old congress area. The artwork was neat and the place really made an impact on me.

Not friendly to non Greek due to the lack of guidance and proper text explanations. If you are Greek and well educated in terms of modern greek history then it works. But overall it is old style museum. In any case, with only 3 euros of entry fee, it is worth visiting.
What a gem in the middle of Athens! For anyone to get a wonderful exposure to Greece's history from 1821 to-date, this is a MUST visit! Enjoy!

Museum has a unique collection of items from the war for independence. Is not big, but very interesting. Impressive building. Sundays entrance is free. But working hours are not for the visitors just if you are early bird you can catch it. Sorry but this must be changed as you are public place.

Interesting artifacts with some English descriptions. Difficult to understand the significance without a thorough knowledge of contemporary Greek history. Not recommended for foreign tourists. Tons of school groups, very distracting from the experience.
Short but sweet. Not much of an art lover myself, but still appreciated the collection of Japanese prints that were there at the time. Check the website for details of the current exhibition.
Very nice place. Free entry for the exhibition I visited and close to the centre. Only downside is that it's close to the metaxourgeio area which seems a bit dangerous..
Fantastic place, many thanks to the mayor
A very interesting Japanese art exhibition from two centuries back

"Japan and the book" was a perfect exhibition, created with the love and care of private collectors, who managed to bring a small portion of this huge culture for people to enjoy! The art of the wood paintings (ukiyo-e) and the book collections of Lafkadio Hern and the first samples of the art of manga, were exquisite and worth researching. Although it's a short exhibition, it's worth your while.

I definitely recommend you visit this fantastic museum at least once during your stay in Athens.

Its purpose is the exhibition of weapon artifacts and the relevant research in the history of war covering Greek history.

The are three floors begining with neolithic and ending on the top floor with World Ward 2 and beyond.

Outside there's a plethora of planes, helicopters, missiles and lots more. Many of these can be sat in if you ask politely.

Inside there is s so much to see that a simple review does not do it justice. There are genuine weapons, artifacts and clothing from many era's. All of which is expertly presented.

In many cases the items (especially weapons) are outside of the glass cases and you are invited to touch and even pick them up.

There are also some very interesting and thought provoking displays. These include several Greek resistance fighters during World World two.

There's also a cafe downstairs, but I didn't have time to visit.

All in all it's a great few hours out with lots to see and I'm sure a lot would keep the kids entertained.

I will definitely be going back again.

Museum gives a good impression of the Greek military history. From the Greek city states to the Greek independence war and WW2. 

All most all information about the displayed items is available in both Greek and English. Sometimes (for instance for some stone age items) is Greek only but that was maybe 5% of the exhibition.

Most interesting parts of the Greek history (for me) were the periods of Alexander The Great and the Greek Independence war. As a Dutch national I never read a lot about the indepence war and it was informative to learn about it and the role the men and women of Greece played in this part of history.

When reading all the information, the main exhibition will take about 2 to 3 hours. There was also another smaller exhibition, but I had to leave for the airport.

In all a very nice museum when you are interested in military or Greek history.

Fairly small museum with a large selection of weaponry from across the millennia. It's particularly focused on 1821 onwards and has an interesting collection of paintings, drawings, and photographs. The aircraft, artillery etc are all outside. €4 entry currently.
Interesting museum. Good overview of Greek history but many explanatory texts only in Greek. Missed oppirtunity
We liked it a lot. Its a medium-sized museum with a good collection of real and copied pieces. Perfect for a rainy day. Nice plains on the entrance. Not so much info in english...

We went on a Thursday, which turned out to have free entry (!), and the museum is open until midnight, so we definitely felt this was very worth going. The museum itself is very cool, although a bit odd - most of the ground floor is all ancient Greek stuff (which was all great stuff, although probably more impressive if you haven't just come from the national Archaeological Museum!), but it then very rapidly transitions into Christian artwork, and then onto much more recent Greek history, including the war for independence on the top floor. We went in not knowing about any of the more recent history, so I don't think we got as much out of the more recent exhibits as we should have done.

Well laid out, authoritative, professional in every way. My focus was Byzantium, but the earlier antiquities are actually the museum's principal strength. Definitely worth visiting. Lovely gift shop and cafe as well.

We had a great experience there. The exhibition is huge and has a lot of interesting objects of art and history.

Probably the first museum where prehistoric artifacts took my breath away. The artwork is truly amazing.

Also there's a cozy canteen with nice service and a good view

One of the best museum i have been visited in Athens. Benaki museum is owned by private organization that it might be a bit more expensive, but it is totally worth the price. It has many collections of cultural artifacts in Greece from Classical to Ottoman, costumes from different regions in Greece islands.
Great museum, with a broad collection of items throughout the history of Greece! Very nice to visit for free on a Thursday evening. Good restaurant as well

Great collection, well laid out. That rare thing: a museum where I actually felt like I was learning a lot, rather than just looking at a bunch of interesting objects. The first floor in particular should be a must-see. All housed in a beautiful building, with a great cafe.
Interesting exhibits and the every day life exhibition in the last floor was remarkable. The staff is so friendly and full of joy. This visit really made my day. A true cultural center.
My favorite museum in Athens. Wonderful English descriptions and historical context. Great, thoughtfully arranged collection. A real joy to walk through.

Rainy day in Athens? You want to stay indoors, visit some place yet stay away from the crowds. Or is it sunny, and unbearably hot? What about a museum where you’ll see many precious things and learn about them, be able to eat well in a lovely courtyard with stunning architecture, and even find out-of-the-ordinary gifts in a beautifully curated shop?
This is one of the finest museums in Athens — and I’d say the favorite in my world.
For, if asked to choose a single piece of art as testimony and heritage of Humanity, I’d pick a Cycladic figurine from this collection.
As an infrequent visitor to Greece, I’ve been visiting this museum since 1990 with renovated pleasure and awe. They seem to make the best of their limited grounds and outstanding collection -- made very informative, entertaining and increasingly beautiful after a successful renovation.

One of my favorite museum from Athens, it would be a shame to miss it. Tip: it's open on Monday and the entrance is 50% off -> 3.50€. You can pick up a nice souvenir from the shop, that can remind you of the Cycladic period.

A marine museum at Floisvos, which contains some Greek historical ships of different kinds. The ships are as follows: warships Averof and Velos, an ancient trireme replica, Thalis o Milisios cable laying steamship, Evangelistria sailing boat.
Battleship of Greece which is now a national relic of 1st world war. At The Hellenic Navy
Ωραίο περιβάλλον και ιστορικά πλοία που αξίζει να επισκεφθείτε.
Ένα μέρος που προβάλλει την ναυτική ιστορία της Ελλάδας.
Sehr schön

This museum was great. I was here for a summer program and stopped by. It was great. Very informative, interesting exhibits about Greece and stuff. Interesting to see the old congress area. The artwork was neat and the place really made an impact on me.

Not friendly to non Greek due to the lack of guidance and proper text explanations. If you are Greek and well educated in terms of modern greek history then it works. But overall it is old style museum. In any case, with only 3 euros of entry fee, it is worth visiting.
What a gem in the middle of Athens! For anyone to get a wonderful exposure to Greece's history from 1821 to-date, this is a MUST visit! Enjoy!

Museum has a unique collection of items from the war for independence. Is not big, but very interesting. Impressive building. Sundays entrance is free. But working hours are not for the visitors just if you are early bird you can catch it. Sorry but this must be changed as you are public place.

Interesting artifacts with some English descriptions. Difficult to understand the significance without a thorough knowledge of contemporary Greek history. Not recommended for foreign tourists. Tons of school groups, very distracting from the experience.

The view is amazing from Mount Lycabettus! You can watch Athens in every direction. It's a silent and peaceful park in the center of the city. Definitely one of the best spots in the city for some photography. Here are some shots I took on my way to the summit.

A Stunning landmark in Athens, the church was beautiful and the view from up there was breathtaking. I was lucky enough to go around sunset, which only enhanced my experience. It's a bit of a hike to get up but absolutely worth the trip. Unfortunately it's bound to be rather overcrowded on most days because of how attractive the spot is for tourists.

We went here as we had nothing else to do and it was a very good choice. A nice view over the city is offered and it is very easily reachable from the city center. You can reach the top by foot or with a cableway (7,50€ round trip).
Good hike. Nice views of Athens. Hard to find the cable ride up the hill so we ended up hiking.

It took about 30 minutes walk from Metro to top of mountain. The hike up is not difficult. The view along the way up is awesome. If you don't mind the hike, it's better than the cable car. Cable car cost €7 round trip.
It's quite windy at the top where the church is located. Many people at the top.
Amazing sunset views along the way up as well.
Recommended

We tried the beef veal Souvlaki and Kebab here. They are tender and juicy and very flavourful . Portion is big enough and i would say it was good value for the money. If you are the type who doesn't eat a lot, 1 portion can be shared between 2 adults. The waiter that served us was warm, welcoming and friendly. Definitely will recommend this to my friends who are visiting Athens.

I love this place so much I went twice! The staff are really good and the food is amazing. 1 meal is enough for 2 adults to share. I spent under €15 for a meal with glasses of wine. Definately well worth going, the chicken soulaki is delicious.
Fantastic food at fantastic prices. Not kebab fan normally but loved these.  A must have in Athens. Family run going for years.

My best dining experience when i was in Athens! I love this place. Only got to dine here once as my stay was short.

The staff that waited our table was cheerful and welcoming. I ordered Greek coffee and the waiter actually went out to get a supposedly popular, aged coffee maker to serve his coffee at our table.

Food portion was generous, pricing was fair. Taste was amazing! You have to give this place a visit.
Amazing Greek salad!!! Great value for money and the staff were very friendly. Well worth a visit 💙🇬🇷
Cosy and warm. A place to be if you want to try grerk traditional cuisine!
Great kitchen to unbeatable prices, the atmosphere is great and the table service was one of the best received in Athen
Silent place with good simple food, good prices (for Athens) and very cheerful staff.
Good food, traditionnal greek food and nice staff ! Everyday the menu is différent and the product are fresh ! I spent a really good time there !
Delicious, authentical and warm! 👌
Can't recommend this restaurant enough. Superb food at a very reasonable price in a lovely atmosphere. Definitely worth seeking out next time you're in Athens.

Was recommended to have lunch here with a Greek friend. The food was traditional and the selection was great! Even though the signboards were mostly in Greek the menu they gave had English translations which helped a lot. Really loved the pie and the stuffed fruits

Super speedy hectic service, a lot of fun to watch all the waiters balancing their plates! Really efficient service, the waiter brings out an appetizer platter for you to choose from before ordering if you don't want to wait! Excellent if you are feeling hungry.

The food is tasty, genuine and really affordable. Plus the setting is pretty cosy, I'd imagine really nice in summer.
We have found whatever we want. Thank you all guys.
From San Jose Costa Rica. Nice place to eat.

A little spot tucked away. They get busy as this is a good place to get some Greek food that is authentic. The wine is good, the food is good, and the service is good. Portions are pretty big for the price and it is delicious. A decent selection of the local cuisine and wine, what more has to be said about a good restaurant? Strongly recommend.

Best kept secret of the locals.  In this posh area, full of fancy restaurants, this place serves good solid Greek specialities.  Also good if you are in a hurry.

It is a bit of a cult phenomenon, sure many famous people know it and come regularly but it maintains true character

Great authentic place! It wasn’t the cosiest place ever but it felt very genuine and authentic. They served super tasty greek food and good wine. The prices were really affordable as well! Great service.

Old fashioned tavern- restaurant with typical well-cooked Greek cuisine. Outside seating during summer time, kind service by knowledgeable waiters. Must try the lamb, meatballs, stuffed cabbage leaves (dolma) and pies of this place. Maybe the most original food in Kolonaki area that is still reasonably priced. Delivery is also available.
Nice traditional restaurant with very good food in a nice environment

The gyro was great, but was tad bit on the salty side so 4, not 5 stars.  They only had pork gyros when I was there - but it does seem the place runs on a, you can order whatever we currently have in stock model. Nevertheless, worth the experience.
This place serve the best souvalki. Run by husband and wife. The queue is normally ling during lunch. Price is very reasonable. Will go back again

Nice quick snack of souvlaki. Friendly couple working there. Decently long line when we arrived but they were efficient and got our order to us quickly. Only 2 seats to eat there so recommend getting takeaway. Very cheap water as well if you're thirsty

The best souvlaki I have ever eat. Beef and the tomato are fresh and juicy! The pita is soft plus the Greek yogurt sauce is wonderful. 
The owner is very nice, and the food is delicious with reasonable price!
Best souvlaki downtown! If you like it dry and clean, it's a must visit! Owners moto: "Without stress"...so go prepared...
It was really good. better than Colorado springs McDonald's.. Everything was fresh thank you

The coke machine is always broken, service is crapy, and the wait is not worth the food. You could go somewhere for better food and get it faster. If you are in a rush go somewhere else, this place is not worth it. To top it all off it is not kid friendly anymore. They have electronic devices that don’t even work half the time. I went once and a baby got run over by a high chair. NOT kid friendly at all.
My weakness! Always a crowd but worth the wait. This location one of the cleanest for being so busy.
Wow looks really nice, so modern, good customer service and they have some good deals.

Nasty food..filthy restaurant .. I am so fed up with the sorry excuse for customer service. I came in today and ordered chicken nuggets, no dipping sauce but 2 packs of mayo, they charged me for the mayo, then tried to give me someone elses food. after they handed my food to the car in front of me, they gave me the same food without replacing it. This place is a horrible location. I will never go back to this location. The sad thing is the owners could care less.
Its the nice place for kids toys. Very nice and helpful staff. Secondly its near by omonia square.
The best toy store in Athens.
Best place to buy a toy for kids
A nice selection of quality  toys some old school toys you won't find anywhere else.
Ποιοτικά παιχνίδια που έρχονται από παλαιότερες εποχές. Διαφορετικές επιλογές.

One of the best hotels I've stayed in. Perfectly situated right in the centre, with stunning views of the Acropolis if you pay a bit extra. I loved the roof-top bar and restaurant, where I had some of the best cocktails I've ever tried (but the price did reflect that) and a superb dinner. The service was impeccable and the staff friendly and informative. I would definitely stay there again.

Exceptional Hotel, great location in the middle of Athens opposite Parliament with quick access to restaurants and clothing stores. Suite was well equipped. Welcome snacks and drinks upon arrival was superb. Breakfast restaurant on the rooftop had every food you could imagine, all fresh and delicious with an amazing view of the Acropolis. Service and staff was average. But all in all a great stay!

So lovely! We had a great view of Parliament and the square. We enjoyed watching the guard. Breakfast buffet and rooftop restaurant were amazing!! The view of the Acropolis from the roof was spectacular.  The central location was handy.

If Old World luxury is your thing, this is the place. Historical 5 stars hotel in the very center of Athens, opposite parliament and home to big political gatherings and demonstrations.
Very well connected, with the metro station just outside the hotel's door, it is the best starting point to explore the near posh and less posh shopping areas.
The hotel is elegant in a discrete way, difficult to find these days. You can use the pools or enjoy the best view in Athens (the Akropolis), especially in the night, in the roof garden bar.
Only complain: no pets allowed...
Love this place. My favourite dining restaurant on the 8th. Staff so kind! Just the door man at the hotel entrance is always grumpy. Never smiles and obviously hates his job. Poor man.
